Header.Title: Climate Change Mitigation Strategies: Economic vs Environmental vs Social Perspectives - Formal Definition

Objective.Description: Analysis of climate change mitigation strategies from three conflicting viewpoints: economic costs, environmental urgency, and social equity considerations.

Context.Description: Evaluation of climate change mitigation strategies through a multi-perspective debate process with 3 experts representing different stakeholder interests.

TaskSpecification.Requirements: With detailed expert positions, numerical ratings (1-10), cross-criticism, and iterative convergence

Expert.Position: Market-based solutions like carbon pricing are most effective

Arguments.Argument: Carbon pricing provides efficient market incentives
Climate policies must address social justice
Just transition for workers is essential

CrossCriticismFramework.Critique: Regulation might be economically inefficient and lead to unintended consequences
Economic growth is necessary to fund social programs
Market mechanisms have failed to address climate urgency
Environmental collapse would harm all communities
Environment policy must consider vulnerable populations

IterativeConvergenceProcess.Synthesis: A hybrid approach combining market mechanisms with regulatory requirements and social safeguards
IterativeConvergenceProcess.AgreedElements: Need for urgent action, diverse approaches, protection of vulnerable populations

OutputFormat.Description: A prompt that will facilitate the debate process and generate detailed analysis
